user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of reply_with_forbidden:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_forbidden (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  static const char page_content[] =
    "<html><head><title>Forbidden</title></head>" \
    "<body>You do not have access to this page.</body></html>";
  static const size_t page_content_len =
    (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
  struct MHD_Response *resp;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len, page_content)
  ;
  if (NULL == resp)
    return MHD_NO;

  /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
     without this header. */
  (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE,
                                  "text/html");

  ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_FORBIDDEN, resp);
  MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the string.h functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in this function. The only manipulation of a string object is the static initialization of page_content with a string literal and the calculation of page_content_len using sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char) - 1, which correctly yields the number of characters excluding the implicit terminating NUL (the literal initialization guarantees the NUL terminator). No pointer arithmetic or manual copying of the buffer is performed here; the call to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static is passed the buffer and its computed length matching the actual buffer size, so there is no apparent off‑by‑one or out‑of‑bounds access in this translation unit. The other calls (MHD_add_response_header, MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response) are to external library functions and contain no direct use of <string.h> functions in this code fragment; any use of string.h inside those library implementations is outside the scope of this function and would need to be reviewed in that library code, not here. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that require investigation for Rule 21.17.
